title: Idiopathic Hypersomnia
icd10: ** G47.11 (Idiopathic hypersomnia with long sleep time)
G47.12 (Idiopathic hypersomnia without long sleep time)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of idiopathic hypersomnia in adults. Covers the diagnostic workup distinguishing IH from narcolepsy type 2, insufficient sleep syndrome, and other causes of excessive daytime sleepiness. Includes PSG/MSLT interpretation, pharmacologic treatment of EDS and sleep inertia/sleep drunkenness, and long-term management. Excludes narcolepsy (separate plan), hypersomnia due to medical conditions, Kleine-Levin syndrome, and medication-induced hypersomnia.

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Exclude anemia contributing to fatigue and hypersomnia
Exclude hypothyroidism as cause of fatigue/hypersomnia
B12 deficiency can cause fatigue and cognitive impairment mimicking IH
Iron deficiency contributes to EDS and restless legs; confounds sleep quality
Exclude substance use causing hypersomnia; mandatory before MSLT

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Comprehensive iron assessment if ferritin borderline; iron deficiency contributes to fatigue
Exclude adrenal insufficiency as cause of fatigue and hypersomnia
Diabetes screening; metabolic contributors to fatigue and sleepiness
Baseline before medication initiation; exclude hepatic encephalopathy
Evaluate for hypothalamic/pituitary dysfunction if structural lesion suspected

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF hypocretin-1 / orexin-A (sent to Stanford reference lab)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Definitively exclude narcolepsy type 1; must be >110 pg/mL to support IH diagnosis
Rare/Specialized.target: >110 pg/mL (excludes NT1); ≤110 pg/mL reclassifies as NT1

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Supportive for narcolepsy if positive (>90% of NT1); absence helps support IH diagnosis but not definitive
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative favors IH over NT1 (but present in 25% of general population)

Essential/First-line.timing: Night before MSLT; required for MSLT interpretation
Essential/First-line.target: Exclude OSA, PLMD, other primary sleep disorders; document total sleep time; note any SOREMP within 15 min

Essential/First-line.timing: Day following PSG; at least 2 weeks off REM-suppressant medications
Essential/First-line.target: Mean sleep latency ≤8 min with <2 SOREMPs (≥2 SOREMPs reclassifies as narcolepsy)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Must have preceding PSG; stop REM-suppressants 2 weeks prior

Essential/First-line.timing: Pre-MSLT; essential to exclude insufficient sleep syndrome
Essential/First-line.target: Document habitual sleep duration ≥7 hours/night; may also demonstrate total sleep ≥11 hours supporting IH with long sleep time

Essential/First-line.timing: Initial evaluation and each follow-up visit

Essential/First-line.target: Confirm adequate habitual sleep (≥7 hours/night); document sleep/wake patterns, nap timing, sleep inertia severity

Extended.timing: If structural lesion suspected (hypothalamic, brainstem) or atypical features
Extended.target: Rule out hypothalamic mass, demyelination, brainstem lesion, hydrocephalus

Extended.timing: If total sleep time criteria needed for diagnosis and actigraphy is equivocal
Extended.target: Document total 24-hour sleep time ≥660 minutes (11 hours); confirms long sleep time phenotype
Extended.contraindications: None; requires dedicated sleep lab with 24-hour monitoring capability

Rare/Specialized.timing: Treatment response monitoring; fitness-for-duty and driving safety evaluation
Rare/Specialized.target: Mean latency >8 min suggests adequate wakefulness (normal >40 min)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If objective sleepiness quantification needed independent of MSLT
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased pupillary unrest correlates with sleepiness

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research setting; alpha power and spectral analysis during wakefulness
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased theta activity in wakefulness may correlate with hypersomnolence

dosing.instructions: Multiple staged alarms at 5-10 minute intervals with escalating volume; place alarms away from bed; consider vibrating alarms, light-based alarms (dawn simulators), and bed-shaking devices; recruit household member for backup awakening

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Sleep inertia; circadian rhythm support; enhance morning alertness

dosing.instructions: 10,000 lux broad-spectrum light box for 30 minutes immediately upon awakening; may combine with dawn simulator alarm; morning light exposure helps consolidate the circadian wake signal

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.contraindications: Retinal conditions; bipolar disorder (may trigger mania); photosensitizing medications

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Consolidate nocturnal sleep; maximize sleep quality

dosing.instructions: Regular sleep-wake schedule (same wake time daily is critical); 7-9 hours nightly; cool dark room; limit screen time before bed; avoid alcohol/sedatives

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Prevent injury from sleepiness and impaired awakening

dosing.instructions: Driving restrictions until EDS controlled; avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery; inform employer; discuss safety risks of sleep drunkenness (e.g., responding to alarms during confusion)

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Prevent worsening of EDS and sleep inertia

dosing.instructions: Avoid alcohol, sedating antihistamines, benzodiazepines; limit caffeine timing (morning only; avoid late-day use that disrupts nocturnal sleep)

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.indication: First-line wake-promoting agent for EDS in IH

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg each morning; increase to 200 mg daily after 1 week; may split 200 mg AM + 200 mg early afternoon if needed; max 400 mg/day; first-line for EDS in IH

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe hepatic impairment; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives
First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.monitoring: Blood pressure; rash (rare Stevens-Johnson syndrome); sleep quality; contraceptive efficacy counseling

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.indication: First-line wake-promoting agent for EDS; longer half-life provides sustained daytime coverage

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg each morning; may increase to 250 mg daily; longer half-life than modafinil provides more sustained wakefulness; max 250 mg/day

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe hepatic impairment; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives
First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.monitoring: Blood pressure; rash (rare Stevens-Johnson syndrome); sleep quality; contraceptive efficacy counseling

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.indication: FDA-approved for IH; only medication demonstrated to reduce total sleep time and improve sleep inertia; REMS program required

dosing.instructions: Start 4.5 g/night divided into 2 equal doses (2.25 g at bedtime + 2.25 g 2.5-4 hours later); titrate by 1.5 g/night every 1-2 weeks; effective range 6-9 g/night; max 9 g/night; FDA-approved for IH (only drug with this indication)

First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.contraindications: Succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency; concurrent sedative-hypnotics or alcohol; concurrent opioids; untreated sleep-disordered breathing
First-Line Pharmacologic Treatment - Wak.monitoring: Respiratory depression; CNS depression; sleepwalking; depression/suicidality screening; sodium levels; REMS compliance monitoring; abuse potential

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.indication: EDS in IH refractory to modafinil/armodafinil; dual dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg once daily upon awakening; may increase to 150 mg daily after ≥3 days; max 150 mg/day; monitor blood pressure as dose-dependent hypertension may occur

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled hypertension; severe renal impairment (eGFR <15); end-stage renal disease
Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; psychiatric symptoms; weight; renal function

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.indication: EDS refractory to first-line agents; rapid onset of action

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID (morning and early afternoon); titrate by 5-10 mg/week; max 60 mg/day; avoid evening dosing; Schedule II controlled substance

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; severe anxiety or agitation; motor tics/Tourette syndrome; glaucoma; structural cardiac abnormalities
Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; weight; appetite; psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential (Schedule II)

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.indication: EDS refractory to first-line agents; potent wake-promoting agent

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID (morning and early afternoon); titrate by 5 mg/week; max 60 mg/day; avoid evening dosing; Schedule II controlled substance

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; advanced atherosclerosis; symptomatic cardiovascular disease; moderate-severe hypertension; glaucoma; agitated states; history of drug abuse
Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; weight; appetite; psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential (Schedule II)

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.indication: EDS in IH; histamine H3 receptor inverse agonist; non-controlled substance

dosing.instructions: Start 8.9 mg once daily upon awakening; titrate weekly: 8.9 mg to 17.8 mg to 35.6 mg; max 35.6 mg/day; non-controlled substance (advantage over stimulants)

Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP2D6 inhibitors (max 17.8 mg); QT-prolonging drugs
Second-Line Pharmacologic Treatment.monitoring: QTc interval if risk factors; hepatic function; insomnia; headache; nausea

Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.indication: Sleep inertia upon awakening; adjunctive to primary wake-promoting therapy

dosing.instructions: 100-200 mg upon awakening (equivalent to 1-2 cups coffee); use as bridge while waiting for primary medication effect; avoid after noon to protect nocturnal sleep quality

Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmias; severe anxiety disorder; gastric ulcer
Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.monitoring: Anxiety; palpitations; sleep quality; tolerance development

Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.indication: Severe sleep inertia/sleep drunkenness refractory to standard treatments; investigational GABA-A receptor antagonist for IH

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg sublingual once daily upon awakening; may increase to 1 mg SL daily; off-label use; limited evidence but promising results in IH; addresses putative GABA-A receptor potentiation in IH pathophysiology

Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.contraindications: Benzodiazepine dependence (may precipitate withdrawal); epilepsy controlled with benzodiazepines; hypersensitivity
Sleep Inertia / Sleep Drunkenness Manage.monitoring: Seizure risk; anxiety; headache; nausea; duration of effect (short half-life may limit efficacy)

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Circadian rhythm support; consolidate nocturnal sleep if fragmented

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg 30 minutes before target bedtime; may help regulate sleep-wake timing; useful if circadian drift present

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Daytime sedation; next-day grogginess; interaction with sleep inertia

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Investigational for IH; negative allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors; off-label

dosing.instructions: 500 mg twice daily; rationale similar to flumazenil (targets GABA-A system); off-label; limited evidence from small studies; potential alternative when flumazenil unavailable

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Macrolide hypersensitivity; concurrent colchicine, pimozide, or cisapride; QT prolongation risk; hepatic impairment
Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: QTc interval; hepatic function; GI side effects; drug interactions (potent CYP3A4 inhibitor); antibiotic stewardship considerations

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine specialist for PSG/MSLT scheduling, diagnosis confirmation, treatment initiation and optimization (IH requires specialist-level interpretation of MSLT results)
Neuropsychology if cognitive complaints are prominent (IH-related cognitive fog requires formal testing to document deficits and guide accommodations)
Occupational medicine for fitness-for-duty evaluation, driving safety assessment, and workplace accommodation (IH poses significant occupational safety risk particularly due to sleep inertia)
Psychiatry if comorbid depression or anxiety requiring treatment (common comorbidities in IH; must distinguish depression-related hypersomnia from IH)
Social work for disability evaluation and community resource coordination (IH causes significant functional impairment; many patients qualify for workplace accommodations under ADA)

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Idiopathic hypersomnia is a chronic neurological condition of the brain's sleep-wake regulation system; it is not laziness, depression, or a behavioral choice
Do not drive until excessive daytime sleepiness is adequately controlled with treatment (risk of drowsy driving is highest in the morning due to sleep inertia)
Use multiple alarm systems with escalating intensity to overcome sleep drunkenness; place alarms away from bed; consider recruiting a household member as backup for important mornings
Naps in IH are typically long and unrefreshing (unlike narcolepsy where short naps are restorative); limit nap duration to 30-60 minutes to avoid worsening sleep inertia from deep nap sleep
Notify all providers about IH diagnosis before any sedation or anesthesia (patients with IH may have prolonged recovery from sedation due to baseline hypersomnolence)
Avoid alcohol and sedating medications (antihistamines, benzodiazepines, muscle relaxants) which worsen excessive sleepiness and sleep drunkenness
If prescribed Xywav (low-sodium oxybate): REMS enrollment required; prepare both doses before bedtime; do not take within 2 hours of food; no alcohol; store securely
Hypersomnia Foundation (hypersomniafoundation.org) for patient resources, support groups, and research updates specific to IH

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain consistent sleep-wake schedule with a strict fixed wake time every day (including weekends) to consolidate the circadian wake signal
Morning light exposure (30 minutes of bright light or outdoor light immediately upon awakening) to counteract sleep inertia and reinforce the circadian wake signal
Regular moderate exercise (30 minutes daily, morning preferred) to improve daytime alertness; avoid vigorous exercise close to bedtime which may fragment sleep
Avoid heavy meals during the day as postprandial sleepiness compounds existing EDS in IH patients
Strategic napping: unlike narcolepsy, naps in IH are generally unrefreshing; if naps are used, limit to 20-30 minutes and set multiple alarms (longer naps worsen sleep inertia)

Inform employer about IH diagnosis for reasonable workplace accommodations under ADA (flexible start time to accommodate sleep inertia, scheduled break periods, avoidance of monotonous or safety-critical tasks during low-alertness periods)
Avoid alcohol and sedatives which exacerbate EDS; limit caffeine to morning hours to avoid disrupting nocturnal sleep quality

differential.features: MSLT shows ≥2 SOREMPs; naps are short and refreshing; less prominent sleep inertia; cataplexy absent (same as IH); MSLT is the primary differentiator
Most common mimic; chronic volitional sleep restriction; resolves with sleep extension to ≥7-8 hours/night; normal MSLT after adequate sleep
differential.tests: Actigraphy ≥2 weeks showing habitual sleep <7 hours; resolution of EDS with sleep extension trial

differential.features: Constitutionally long sleep need (≥10 hours) but feel refreshed upon awakening; no EDS when sleep need is met; no sleep drunkenness
differential.tests: Sleep extension trial: EDS resolves when full sleep need met; ESS normal when well-rested

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication initiation (sedating antidepressants, antipsychotics, antihistamines, anticonvulsants, opioids); resolves with dose reduction or discontinuation
differential.tests: Medication review; temporal correlation; MSLT normalizes after medication discontinuation

differential.features: Depressed mood, anhedonia, psychomotor retardation; fatigue more than true sleepiness; may have increased time in bed but MSLT usually normal; sleep often fragmented
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; PHQ-9 ≥10; MSLT typically mean latency >8 min and <2 SOREMPs

differential.features: Snoring, witnessed apneas, obesity; EDS improves with CPAP; no sleep drunkenness; fragmented sleep on PSG
differential.tests: PSG with respiratory scoring; AHI >5 events/hour; EDS resolves with CPAP treatment

differential.features: Fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation, dry skin; generalized slowing; no SOREMPs
differential.tests: TSH elevated; free T4 low; EDS resolves with thyroid replacement

differential.features: Recurrent episodes of profound hypersomnia lasting days-weeks with cognitive and behavioral disturbances (hyperphagia, hypersexuality, derealization); completely asymptomatic between episodes
differential.tests: Episodic pattern (recurrence-remission); normal inter-episode PSG/MSLT; onset typically in adolescence

differential.features: EDS developing after TBI; temporal relationship to head injury; may have prolonged sleep time similar to IH; may or may not resolve over time
differential.tests: History of TBI preceding hypersomnia; neuroimaging may show injury; onset within 6-12 months of TBI

differential.features: Misalignment of endogenous circadian rhythm (delayed sleep-wake phase disorder most common); sleepiness is time-of-day dependent
differential.tests: Actigraphy showing delayed sleep-wake phase; sleep log; DLMO (dim light melatonin onset)

evidence.recommendation: ICSD-3-TR diagnostic criteria for idiopathic hypersomnia (daily EDS ≥3 months, <2 SOREMPs, mean latency ≤8 min or total sleep ≥660 min, insufficient sleep excluded)
evidence.source: [AASM. International Classification of Sleep Disorders, 3rd ed., Text Revision (ICSD-3-TR) 2023](https://aasm.org/)

evidence.recommendation: Comprehensive review of IH pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management; evidence for GABA-A receptor potentiation hypothesis
Flumazenil as treatment for IH targeting GABA-A receptor abnormality; demonstrated improvement in subjective sleepiness and sleep inertia
Diagnosis of central disorders of hypersomnolence; distinction between IH and narcolepsy type 2; MSLT limitations and biomarker development
Low-sodium oxybate (Xywav) efficacy for IH; reduced EDS, sleep inertia, and total sleep time; basis for FDA approval in IH
IH treatment update; review of modafinil, stimulants, oxybate, pitolisant, and investigational agents for IH management
evidence.source: [Ali et al. J Clin Sleep Med 2023](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37082825/)

evidence.recommendation: Modafinil efficacy for EDS; first-line wake-promoting agent (evidence primarily from narcolepsy trials, extrapolated to IH)
evidence.source: [US Modafinil in Narcolepsy Multicenter Study Group. Neurology 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10720292/)

evidence.recommendation: Solriamfetol efficacy for EDS; dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (FDA approved for narcolepsy and OSA; off-label for IH)
Pitolisant efficacy for EDS; histamine H3 inverse agonist; non-controlled substance option (off-label for IH)
European guideline on management of central hypersomnolence; treatment recommendations applicable to IH (modafinil/armodafinil first-line for EDS)
Xywav REMS program required for prescribing; FDA mandate for safety monitoring
MSLT interpretation and validation; <2 SOREMPs with mean latency ≤8 min distinguishes IH from NT2

monitoring.frequency: Each visit (every 3 months during titration; every 6 months when stable)
monitoring.action: Adjust wake-promoting agent dose; add second agent; switch therapy; consider Xywav
Correlate with ESS and functional status; adjust treatment accordingly
Optimize Xywav dosing (most effective for sleep inertia); adjust alarm strategy; consider flumazenil

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; more frequently if on stimulants or solriamfetol
monitoring.action: Dose reduction; add antihypertensive; switch to non-stimulant agent
Dose reduction; cardiology referral if persistent tachycardia
Dietary counseling; exercise; evaluate medication effects (stimulants may cause weight loss, inactivity from hypersomnia may cause weight gain)
Psychiatric referral; adjust medications; monitor suicidality; distinguish IH-related cognitive fog from depression

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; 1 month after initiation; then every 6 months
monitoring.action: Dietary sodium counseling; dose adjustment; endocrine evaluation if persistently abnormal
Re-enroll if lapsed; review adherence barriers; verify prescriber/pharmacy enrollment

monitoring.frequency: Every 6-12 months; sooner if symptoms worsen
monitoring.action: Reinforce driving restrictions; consider MWT for formal assessment; adjust treatment
Consider non-stimulant alternatives (pitolisant, Xywav); refer to addiction medicine if indicated

monitoring.frequency: Annually; more frequently if on pitolisant or clarithromycin
monitoring.action: Dose reduction or discontinuation of hepatotoxic medication

disposition.criteria: Majority of patients; newly suspected or established IH for diagnostic workup and chronic management; almost all IH management is outpatient
Patients requiring in-lab polysomnography followed by next-day MSLT; ensure REM-suppressants discontinued ≥2 weeks prior
Rare; if extended monitoring needed to document total 24-hour sleep time ≥660 minutes when actigraphy is equivocal or technically inadequate
Rarely indicated; severe sleep drunkenness causing immediate safety concern (e.g., patient living alone unable to awaken for emergencies); concurrent medical condition requiring inpatient management
All patients with suspected IH for PSG/MSLT interpretation, diagnosis confirmation, and treatment initiation
Atypical presentation; suspected secondary cause of hypersomnia; treatment-refractory cases
Every 2-4 weeks during initial medication titration; every 3 months during first year; every 6 months once stable
